section.title: How cURL Commands Work
section.para: cURL is a command-line tool that you can use to interact with Representational State Transfer (REST) interfaces. cURL lets you to transmit and receive HTTP requests and responses from the command line or a shell script, which enables you to work with the API directly. It is available for Linux distributions, Mac OS X, and Windows. For information about cURL, see http://curl.haxx.se/.
To easily run cURL examples in this guide, export your account id and authentication token. For more information, see “Exporting cURL Environment Variables”“Exporting cURL Environment Variables”

section.para: The cURL examples in this guide use the following command-line options:

td.para: Sends the specified data in a request to the HTTP server. Use this option to send a JSON request body to the server.
Specifies an extra HTTP header in the request. You can specify any number of extra headers. Precede each header with the -H option.

Common headers in Rackspace API requests are as follows:
Content-Type. Required for operations with a request body.
Specifies the format of the request body. Following is the syntax for the header where format is either json or xml. Content-Type: application/format
X-Auth-Token. Required. Specifies the authentication token.
Accept. Optional.
Specifies the format of the response body. Following is the syntax for the header where format is either json or xml. The default is json. Accept: application/format
Includes the HTTP header in the output.
Specifies silent or quiet mode, which makes cURL mute. No progress or error messages are shown.
Transfers the specified local file to the remote URL.
Specifies the request method to use when communicating with the HTTP server. The specified request is used instead of the default method, which is &GET;.

section.title: Exporting cURL Environment Variables
section.para: To run the cURL requests shown in this guide, export your tenant ID and the token that you got during authentication (see “Authenticate through the Rackspace Cloud Identity Service”) to environment variables and then copy the example from this guide to the command line, script, or tool, changing URI parameters or body parameters as needed.

To export environment variables:
Export your tenant ID to the account environment variable: $ export account="tenantID"
Where tenantID is your account ID.
Export your authentication token to the token environment variable: $ export token="token_id"
Where token_id is the authentication token value in the id field of the token element in the authentication response. For information about finding the token ID, see “Authentication Response”.
